Issues.Title: Invalid PInvoke definition for SafeNativeMethods.GetThemeMargins()
Issues.Body:
`VisualStyleRenderer.GetMargins(...)` throws an AccessViolation because of an invalid PInvoke definition for `SafeNativeMethods.GetThemeMargins(...)`
According to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/uxtheme/nf-uxtheme-getthememargins the LPCRECT parameter is missing. 
The method is currently not used as far as I can see, but its wrong behavior is mentioned in some code comments.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Invalid PInvoke definition for SafeNativeMethods.GetThemeMargins()" (#526)

Issues.Title: No more Microsoft Sans Serif, return actual system font from SystemFonts.DefaultFont?
Issues.Body:
Is this a good time to fix a long-standing issue, the default use of Microsoft Sans Serif 8pt instead of Segoe UI 9pt? This is in violation of Microsoft's [design guidelines](https://docs.microsoft.com/windows/desktop/uxguide/vis-fonts#guidelines):

> UI technology | Target Windows version | Fonts to use and optimize for
> -- | -- | --
> Win32 or WinForms | Windows Vista or later | Use the appropriate Segoe UI font.
>
> - Developers:
>
>   - For elements that use fixed layout (such as Windows dialog templates and WinForms), hard code the appropriate font from the preceding table.

The only member of `SystemFonts` that reflects the actual system theme is the unintuitively-named `SystemFonts.MessageBoxFont`. Anything in `SystemFonts` that's **not returning Segoe UI** on a default installation of Windows should either change and start returning the real value or should be obsoleted. In other words, https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.drawing.systemfonts#properties should line up precisely with https://docs.microsoft.com/windows/desktop/uxguide/vis-fonts#fonts-and-colors on current Windows installations. Tahoma is not okay and Microsoft Sans Serif is not okay.

These guidelines are consistent with Microsoft's font guidelines for other UI technologies.

If Segoe UI was defaulted effortlessly, it would be a huge benefit! The fight against Microsoft Sans Serif has afflicted every Windows Forms project I've worked on, large and small. I also see apps being built that didn't undertake this uphill battle and which stand out visually as less professional as a result. Here's an example taken from the second link below:

> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8040367/53685746-d0877f00-3cec-11e9-985e-f3ede3b0a6c8.png)

History and hacks to get it working:

- https://weblogs.asp.net/kdente/394499
- https://benhollis.net/blog/2007/04/11/setting-the-correct-default-font-in-net-windows-forms-apps/
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "No more Microsoft Sans Serif, return actual system font from SystemFonts.DefaultFont?" (#524)

Issues.Title: Anchored WinForms controls inside FlowLayoutPanel are not actually anchored
Issues.Body:
The example at [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/winforms/controls/how-to-anchor-and-dock-child-controls-in-a-flowlayoutpanel-control) article demonstrates the problem.
Basically, when the form is resized, FlowLayoutPanel does resize, but the controls inside it don't stay anchored as they should.

To better understand, compare these pictures:

![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13788125/53681960-64f7de80-3cf9-11e9-9fe7-045ba111a3c0.PNG)
![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13788125/53681966-780aae80-3cf9-11e9-9b6a-62e993a58be6.PNG)

The button "Anchored=Left, Right" should have stretched.

Environment:
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Preview
Version 16.0.0 Preview 4.0
VisualStudio.16.Preview/16.0.0-pre.4.0+28625.133
Microsoft .NET Framework
Version 4.7.03056
and
![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13788125/53682176-bdc87680-3cfb-11e9-8677-d2d7b93b94aa.PNG)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Anchored WinForms controls inside FlowLayoutPanel are not actually anchored" (#522)

Issues.Title: [WebBrowser] HtmlElement.AttachEventHandler does nothing
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: v3.0.0-preview2
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**

HtmlElement's AttachEventHandler method is a no-operation in .NET Core 3. Here's a simple repro:

```
var browser = new WebBrowser
{
    Dock = DockStyle.Fill,
    DocumentText = @"<!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta http-equiv='Content-Type' content='text/html;charset=utf-8' />
    <meta http-equiv='X-UA-Compatible' content='IE=edge' />
  </head>
  <body>
    <input id='foo'/>
  </body>
</html>"
};
browser.DocumentCompleted += (sender, args) =>
    browser.Document.GetElementById ("foo").AttachEventHandler ("oninput", (s, a) => Console.WriteLine ("this does not fire"));

var form = new Form();
form.Controls.Add (browser);
form.ShowDialog();
```

Note that @AaronRobinsonMSFT is aware of the issue and has done some investigation on the coreclr side.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[WebBrowser] HtmlElement.AttachEventHandler does nothing" (#520)

Issues.Title: Repository organisation
Issues.Body:
It is a question/discussion more than anything.

I find the physical organisation (left) of the repo somewhat confusing as it has quite different layout to the logical organisation (right):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/53677251-f7e84700-3d00-11e9-990d-78a5653e2f7e.png)

The downside of this differences is a higher cognitive load and reduced discoverability of elements in the repo, as well as very confusing namespace organisation for the tests.

Few random examples:

* `BitmapEditorTests` lives under "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors\tests\UnitTests". 
Not withstanding that it is actually a suite of tests for `MockBitmapEditor` (that resides in "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors\tests\UnitTests\Mocks"), one would reasonably expect to find `BitmapEditor` in "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors\src". 
However the actual `BitmapEditor` class is found under "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors\src\System\Drawing\Design" and the its namespace is `System.Drawing.Design` and not `System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors`.
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/f25dc3d526b121ab9adbff3b5779c856a07afa78/src/System.Windows.Forms.Design.Editors/tests/UnitTests/BitmapEditorTests.cs#L8-L30

* There is `ButtonTests` that live under "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\tests\UnitTests" and the SUT is located under "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms"
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/3ce29ac28e6cf25dbb3538543c98376f1d7a0da9/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/UnitTests/ButtonTests.cs#L9-L21
The namespace match, all good.
Then there is `ColumnStyleTests` that lives under "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\tests\UnitTests\System\Windows\Forms" yet the SUT is found in "winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms" (the SUT is also defined in `TableLayoutSettings.cs`, which further increases the confusion).


What is a reason for modelling the repo in its current state?
Why tests for classes defined in same namespaces are placed in very different physical locations?
Should/could the physical organisation be aligned with the logical organisation?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Repository organisation" (#519)

Issues.Title: Having troubles running integration tests
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0.100-preview-010024, master @ ea3a2cec28af1e0248460a93c14942078090a2b8
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: N/A

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**

Running `.\build -integrationTest` or running integration tests from VS result in errors:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/53564547-4be11780-3bab-11e9-8141-3fcbcd3a6c22.png)


**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->

No stacks readily available except for the error popup.

**Expected behavior:**

Tests run successfully
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Having troubles running integration tests" (#508)
